Hello! I really screwed up an update with Backdrop and after a restore, I'm going to move cautiously! Would appreciate some help here!
So, the proper procedure for an UPDATE is to replace ONLY the Core Directory? Is that right? Annotation-2020-09-09-142319.png

Hi, Frederick Wright. Welcome to the Backdrop CMS community on Zulip. I'm your friendly neighborhood Dragonbot. Try '@Dragonbot help' for a list of things I can help you with. There are lots of friendly humans that hang around here, so please feel free to ask questions.

Here is a short (3 min) video to help you navigate Zulip. https://youtu.be/DN8YL2MrsSU

That is correct, but first read the release notes to make sure some files not in core (like .htaccess, settings.php, etc.) were not modified.
And, if you want to really play it safe, first rename core to something else like core-backup, so you have it handy to revert back to, if necessary.
BTW Backdrop can update core via UI. That's the by far easiest way, no need to fiddle with directories on the server.

indigoxela said:

BTW Backdrop can update core via UI. That's the by far easiest way, no need to fiddle with directories on the server.

That was one of the things I really love about backdrop and hated about D7.
I've heard a lot of talk today about people being busy updating websites. Is that because of the security releases yesterday?

I have ~10 Drupal sites and ~10 Backdrop sites, and I updated all mine 24 hours ago. Mine are easy because they all use Drupal's/Backdrop's multisite feature (so I only have one instance of Drupal and Backdrop to update).
But everytime this happens I get worried I'm doing it wrong...
I mean, if others are still updating their sites 24 hours later, am I not testing thoroughly, should I not be using multisites, am I missing something important...?
It's like doing an exam and handing yours in in half the time others take, then wondering what questions you missed :laughing:

It might not have anything to do with the upgrade itself, but more the infrastructure around it. With multisite, it can be quicker and easier, but with single site, and a dev/test/live and peer review/QA workflow, it can get a lot more time consuming just to get the same update through to production.
I do all my work on live sites :big_smile: (clients are small enough that it's not an issue, and I have daily backups if needbe).
